    <li> Just bought these myself to replace a set of old, cheap electromagnetic clippers - and the difference is night and day. These are much more solid, much more powerful, and much quicker to do their job than the others.    This is the same mechanism in Wahl&#x27;s other home-grade clippers - a traditional rotating electric motor driving the shears by gears and levers - NOT a simple oscillating magnetic field coil coaxing a plastic arm back and forth as the A/C current reverses at 60Hz. You can&#x27;t stop these blades without stalling a rotating motor - which means even the thickest hair is going to be cut easily - I suspect it would go through fine copper wire just as well (although that won&#x27;t improve your blades&#x27; condition). What do you people have against lions?  Nothing, that&#x27;s what.    I then ran it through the brutal obstacle course of my head, throwing endless armies of brambled follicles, the kind with mean streaks and meaner grins, who drink straight from the milk jug and don&#x27;t wash their hands enough, and have tattoos with the names of all their enemies and ex-lovers.  Hair with tattoos, you heard it here first.  The trimmer took one look and mowed them down with relaxed fury, literally cutting them down to size (eight available with this set, create your own style today!) in crisp, uniform lengths. Note: Product not authorized for landscaping work, I playfully made that up.  Doublenote: OR WAS I? You can also pair this up with different attachments from Wahl, including [[ASIN:B000UZEQK0 Wahl #12 clipper guide comb, 1&amp;1/2.]] for longer style cuts.  They snap right on without issue, useful for those wanting heftier styles.  This does lend some useful versatility to the product, which I appreciate.  You will appreciate it too.  The case gets the job done, but it does lack any kind of internal organization - there&#x27;s nothing to slot the attachments into, for example.  Things will jumble around and get disorganized, but this is a minor complaint.  There is enough room for another few attachments in addition to the included stock, as it is roomy enough to accommodate a few added accessories.   The cord could probably bit a tiny bit longer.  Most things are better longer.  Except for hair, which is why you are buying this thing in the first place.  In short: highly recommended.  Manly recommended.  Grab you one and unleash the wonderful mightiness.  Hold it high above your newly clean-cut head and watch lighting bolts dance behind you as you part the heavens in your magnificence.</li>

    <li> I am not a barber but I do cut my own hair as well as my friends&#x27; hair, and have had cheaper clippers which have been lost or broken, or thrown away in frustration over poor quality.  I have seen reviews here stating that these Wahl clippers suffer from a variety of quality related defects.  In my case it is just the opposite.  No, I don&#x27;t work for Wahls or know anyone who does, to make that clear, I&#x27;m just offering my personal opinion.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;The pair of clippers I got are very nice.  I never use scissors, only clippers like these.  I have bought clippers five times before, these Wahls are either the nicest or are tied for it.  The Wahls website includes video instruction which are clear, short and simple.  Once you have the confidence, cutting hair is a simple task, made nearly idiot proof and so cheap as to boggle the mind.  I&#x27;ve saved hundreds of dollars personally, and thousands if friends and family are included over time.  At $15 a cut, 12 cuts per year, it&#x27;s $180 a year per person, call it near $10,000 over a lifetime.  That&#x27;s a lot of hair.  Owning clippers makes this as easy as picking money up off the ground.  Would you bend over and pick up $10,000?  Then reach down and click your mouse...&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;These are very well made clippers.  They are heavy and feel solid in the hand.  They are quite obviously designed for serious use.  They feel warm and solid in my hand, humming away with a low, steady tone.  A great feature in these clippers is the POWER screw in the side.  People who complain about the noise either haven&#x27;t ever used clippers or have a defective set or (probably) don&#x27;t realize that this screw is there to address the issue of a poor or low current to the unit.  Low power current results in a louder than expected buzzing sound.  The screw is adjusted with a Phillips head and results in a quieter unit that is more efficient.  It is an adjustment only found in high quality clippers, as it adds to the cost of making the clippers.  The clipper housing is heavy gauge extruded plastic which can absorb the occasional drop, smack and fumble.  I&#x27;ve mentioned owning clippers before.  Common problems are a cheap, plasticky feel, lack of heft so it feels like you are holding a squirt gun not a tool, and poor or dull cutting teeth which can rip or tear hair not cut it cleanly.  Cheap clippers also break over time.  None of these problems afflict my Wahl clippers, though I see complaints about them elsewhere.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;This set comes in a clamshell plastic box which contains a color coded set of guides, which is very nice as the guides are commonly all black.  They identify length by number, #1 being shortest at 1/8th of an inch, #8 longest at an inch.  Ear guides are handy and clearly labeled for left and right ears.  Oddly, eyebrow guides are included, for the hobbits among us.  The colored guides are a handy system that prevents confusion.  The color key is added to the clipper body so you can glance at your hand to see both the color of the clipper guide on the unit and the length the color printed on the clippers.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;The set includes cleaning brush, comb, clippers, guides, oil (nice touch as a small amount prevents an additional purchase until it runs out) and scissors all held together in a clamshell plastic box with clips to hold it securely shut.  The box  has enough room to hold everything and not get frustrated trying to cram it all in.  It would benefit a lot from the addition of a single item, a cape to prevent hair from getting all over your clothes. The color key is added to the clipper body so you can glance at your hand to see both the color of the clipper guide on the unit and the length the color printed on the clippers.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;The set includes cleaning brush, comb, clippers, guides, oil (nice touch as a small amount prevents an additional purchase until it runs out) and scissors all held together in a clamshell plastic box with clips to hold it securely shut. It would benefit a lot from the addition of a single item, a cape to prevent hair from getting all over your clothes.  If this was included I would have given 5 stars as it would represent that thoughtful addition that demonstrates the manufacturer provides not just what is required but offers the consideration that goes that extra distance which separates a good value from the perfect purchase.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;I hope this review helps you in your decision.</li>

Common sense right? So what I did was play it safe and started with a 7 going all the way around my sides and back. Then taking a 6, I went up to the middle part of my head, slightly above the top of the ear. With a 5, I went to about the middle of my ear. Essentially what this does is create a natural taper where it blends nicely since you started with the longer clipper going all the way around, and gradually got shorter as you moved down your head.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;After doing this I thought it was a bit too long still so I repeated the process going 5-4-3.
